newsitem.title: INDONESIA: World businesses urged to cash in on ASEAN growth.
newsitem.headline: World businesses urged to cash in on ASEAN growth.

text.p: Indonesian President Suharto on Wednesday urged business leaders from Asia, Europe and North America to seize the advantages of the explosive growth forecast for Southeast Asia over the next decades.

"ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) will become one of the regions with the highest economic growth in the world in the decades to come," Suharto said in opening the first ASEAN Business summit.

"As a result, a synergy is necessary -- whether between the government and businessmen, amongst ASEAN businessmen themselves and between ASEAN and non-ASEAN businessmen," he said. "This is achieved .. by seizing opportunities within ASEAN and even outside ASEAN."
Some 600 business leaders from 30 countries, including about 200 from the United States, are attending the two-day summit in Jakarta.

Participants have said that with the adoption of an ASEAN Free Trade Area by 2003 and liberalisation of trade between Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) countries by 2020, the region should record explosive growth in the early part of the 21st century.
They have said Southeast Asia should have one billion consumers and $2.0 trillion in combined gross domestic product by 2020, up from the current 400 million and about $600 billion respectively.
ASEAN comprises Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam and Brunei. Cambodia, Laos and Burma are expected to join the bloc this year.
"ASEAN is going to be important in the future," said meeting participant Richard Childress, who heads the Washington-based Asian Investment Strategies consultancy.

"There are going to be a lot of private contacts and networking, but more importantly, we have come with a collective message: 'We take the place very seriously'," he added, referring to the size of the U.S. business delegation attending the meeting.
Other participants said the delegation was the largest collection of businessmen from the United States to visit Indonesia.
Suharto told the gathering that ASEAN's location and abundant economic resources made it a strategic production base.
"The increasingly rapid (economic) liberalisation process will simultaneously offer new market opportunities and new challenges," he said.
"I hope ASEAN businessmen can develop new initiatives for the promotion of small and medium enterprises which have great potential for the creation of employment opportunities...," he said.

Suharto called for a reliable partnership between business and government and "a common ASEAN vision" to lead the region towards its goals of economic liberalisation and free trade over the next couple of decades.
